hints_html:
Recall that radioactive decay is an example of exponential decay, described by the formula \(\displaystyle y(t) = Ce^{kt}\), where \(y(t)\) is the percentage of material left after t years, and C is the initial amount.

Before you can calculate the current amount remaining, you will have to use the information about half-life to find k.

With a half life of 29 year, expect more than 50% of the material to be remaining at 26 years.
hints_latex:
Recall that radioactive decay is an example of exponential decay,
described by the formula $\displaystyle y(t) = Ce^{kt}$, where $y(t)$ is
the percentage of material left after \emph{t} years, and \emph{C} is
the initial amount.

Before you can calculate the current amount remaining, you will have to
use the information about half-life to find \emph{k}.

With a half life of 29 year, expect more than 50\% of the material to be
remaining at 26 years.
hints_raw:
Recall that radioactive decay is an example of exponential decay, described by the formula <math> \displaystyle y(t) = Ce^{kt}</math>, where <math>y(t)</math> is the percentage of material left after ''t'' years, and ''C'' is the initial amount.
Before you can calculate the current amount remaining, you will have to use the information about half-life to find ''k''.
With a half life of 29 year, expect more than 50% of the material to be remaining at 26 years.
question: B 05
sols_html:
As stated in the second hint, we will first use the information about half-life to solve for the rate of decay, or k in the equation:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y(t) = Ce^{kt}\end{aligned}\]

If \(y(t)\) is the percentage remaining after \(t\) years, we know that \(50\%\) of 90Sr remains after 29 years. At t = 0 the amount is 100 percent, hence choose C = 100. Plugging this into the formula gives:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 50 = 100e^{k29}\end{aligned}\]

Solving for \(k\), we get

\(\ln(\frac12) = 29k\)

\(\displaystyle k = \ln(1/2)/29\)

Plugging this back into our formula for \(y(t)\), we can now solve for the percentage remaining on April 26, 2012, when \(t = 26\).

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y(t) = 100e^{(\ln(1/2)/29)*26}\end{aligned}\]

Simplifying will give:

\[\begin{aligned} y(t) = 100*(\frac12)^{26/29}\end{aligned}\]

or 53% remaining.
sols_raw:
As stated in the second hint, we will first use the information about half-life to solve for the rate of decay, or ''k'' in the equation:

:<math> \displaystyle y(t) = Ce^{kt}</math>

If <math>y(t)</math> is the percentage remaining after <math>t</math> years, we know that <math>50%</math> of <sup>90</sup>Sr remains after 29 years.  At ''t = 0'' the amount is 100 percent, hence choose ''C = 100''. Plugging this into the formula gives: 

:<math> \displaystyle 50 = 100e^{k29}</math>

Solving for <math>k</math>, we get

<math>\ln(\frac12) = 29k</math>

<math>\displaystyle k = \ln(1/2)/29</math>

Plugging this back into our formula for <math>y(t)</math>, we can now solve for the percentage remaining on April 26, 2012, when <math>t = 26</math>.  

:<math> \displaystyle y(t) = 100e^{(\ln(1/2)/29)*26}</math>

Simplifying will give:

:<math>y(t) = 100*(\frac12)^{26/29}</math> 

or 53% remaining.
statement_html: In the Chernobyl reactor explosion, which occurred on April 26, 1986, substantial amounts of the isotope strontium-90 (90Sr) contaminated the area around the nuclear plant. 90Sr decays at a rate proportional to its quantity. 90Sr has a half-life of 29 years; that is, it takes 29 years for a quantity of 90Sr to decrease by half. What is the proportion of 90Sr originally released which remains on April 26, 2012?
statement_latex:
In the Chernobyl reactor explosion, which occurred on April 26, 1986,
substantial amounts of the isotope strontium-90 (\textsuperscript{90}Sr)
contaminated the area around the nuclear plant. \textsuperscript{90}Sr
decays at a rate proportional to its quantity. \textsuperscript{90}Sr
has a half-life of 29 years; that is, it takes 29 years for a quantity
of \textsuperscript{90}Sr to decrease by half. What is the proportion of
\textsuperscript{90}Sr originally released which remains on April 26,
2012?
statement_raw: In the Chernobyl reactor explosion, which occurred on April 26, 1986, substantial amounts of the isotope strontium-90 (<sup>90</sup>Sr) contaminated the area around the nuclear plant. <sup>90</sup>Sr decays at a rate proportional to its quantity. <sup>90</sup>Sr has a half-life of 29 years; that is, it takes 29 years for a quantity of <sup>90</sup>Sr to decrease by half. What is the proportion of <sup>90</sup>Sr originally released which remains on April 26, 2012?
